text: This spot is closed at the original spot it is now in Alsip Illinois 111th and Pulaski

They weren't the best hot dogs in Chicago, and they didn't serve Chicago style hotdogs. They snapped too much. But they were addictive, and cheap. And their fries were the best. Never had better anywhere. I can't listen to the band Chicago without thinking of this place. Great donuts in the morning too. It's definitely missed.

I was very young when I started going here. It used to be a treat when we were downtown and on the way home we would stop. I would beg to go. I loved this small little place that not many people got to go to. I wish it was still around. It was a landmark that should have never been torn down. I can not tell you how much it sucks thinking about it being gone. Very few picture i can find of this place. If the owners of this place read this I hope you understand how much your place meant to me as a child. It was a rare treat but it was one I always looked forward to.

As it's the 100th review time again, I will once again review a departed business. I'll always miss Demon Dogs. Where the heck else can I find $2 hot dog and fries anymore in Chicago? Wish they could've opened a new location in the parking lot east of the station, or somewhere else in the neighborhood. It was such a great place, that I can forgive them for the piped-in Chicago music, and Chicago band memorabilia. Finding a cheap place to eat in that area has never been the same, since Demon Dogs closed.

Demon Dogs was a landmark, and is still the reigning champ for BEST HOT DOG in Chicago, and therefor the world.  The fries were cooked in lard which left little fat on the fries and added enough salty flavor for them to be the single most addictive things on the planet.  The hot dogs were all Viena Beef, were cooked perfectly and were all around works of art, especially before/after a cubs game.   The only reason the place was closed was due to an expansion of The Fullerton EL stop, which was only done in a failed effort to increase Metro capacity for an Olympic bid which was lost anyway because the Olympic committee are two faced idiots.   I would seriously put thousands into a rebuilding of this landmark, if only to get one more meal and a t-shirt.  Someone get Metro on the line and have them open this puppy back up!
Quite possibly the best hot dog I ever ate. Best cheese fries too. I have yet to find anything that compares, and lament the loss every time I visit Chicago.

It needs to come back.  I  grew up in Lincoln Park and would beg my mom to take us there.  I didn't have it until high school.  Chicago institution.  One of many that has disappeared.  Is anyone else worried that this city is losing its  character?

I used to eat at this place before going back to my dorm, but I am sad that they closed the fries were really good. CTA had been trying to get them to close for some time in order to remodel the Fullerton station. The only reason they stayed in buisness was because of the DePaul students who patronized this place for nearly 30 years. The only reason it was a hot spot was because singer and Chicago native Jeremy Jordan would eat here on a frequent basis. I loved the fresh cut fries which were delicious even though they were a little greasy. The hot dogs were good since I was about having them with ketchup. Plus the owner was the one who produced the band and DePaul alum Chicago and the place had a lot of Chicago memorabilia from their early days and past albums. If you wanted a quick meal for a small price you got it at Demon Dogs.

RIP Demon Dogs... you will be missed! Quite possibly the best hot dog in the city. The prices can't be beat (under $2 for hotdog and fries) and the location is key. Although it was always crowded, the service was fast. Who could forget all of the fun decorations and memorabilia?  I really hope this place resurfaces...it was fantastic! The only reason it's not getting a 5 star review is because its closed...

Very sad that it closed.  Was a classic Chicago Hot Dog stand in an extremely convient location.  No more Demon Dogs, Fields, Carson's on State Street.  So many of the Chicago traditions are melting away, very sad!!

Oh man, CLOSED! Bring it back. I've eaten uncountable numbers of polish-only-hot-peppers and fries here. They got me because of the location (transferring from El to bus on the way home) but I kept coming back because they served a rock-solid, reliable dog every time! Wah!

Visiting friends in Chicago, I asked around for the best dogs in town. I was directed towards this place, situated under a train station? If you want a hotdog, they'll give you a hotdog. Doesn't compare to the variety and health hazardness of Pinks in Los Angeles. It's just a dog, dawg...
this place was so great. another reason to hate the brown line. RIP demon dogs. too bad i gave the demon dogs t-shirt i had to my ex bf. we all make mistakes.

Former kick ass hot dog HQ.  I'm sorry to see it go.  I'm also getting tired of Chicago's "everything needs to be brand new" policy.  Yeah, the EL stop is old, but so what.  Whatever happened to character?  I think the closing was pure politics.  DD supposedly is going to reopen somewhere else, but I don't believe it.

Closed, why ... why ... sweet lord why, can't you see I'm ready to sell my soul ;) for a Demon Dog here. Well, going to DePaul just hasn't been the same since the lost their fight to stay open. I ... like many others, miss this place. (Perhaps if I were a Demon I could have some one wish they would re-open it ... and ... and ... nothing happened... I suck at being a mystical being.) This place was a Chicago institution, one of the few places that actually served authentic Chicago style dogs. Sadly missed, but not forgotten.
I miss this place - wish that they would re-open it - this institution actually served real Chicago style hot dogs.
Well, Demon Dogs lost its fight for survival a couple of months ago, it served some great hot dogs & fries in its time but now it is closed for good.

This hot dog stand has survived rumours of it's closing. Located right underneath the Ravenswood El stop at Fullerton and close to DePaul's campus, this infamous stand is filled with photos of the band Chicago (owner is or was their manager) as well as other bands and celebs.  The dogs are pretty good too.  Get a bow wow with everything.  And of course make it Chicago style!
